definition:
A morphism $f: A \longrightarrow B$ in a category is an *isomorphism* if
there exists a morphism $f^{-1}: B \longrightarrow A$ which is its
inverse. The objects $A$ and $B$ are *isomorphic* if there is an
isomorphism between them.

A morphism which is both an isomorphism and an endomorphism is called an
*automorphism*. The set of automorphisms of an object $A$ is denoted
$\operatorname{Aut}(A)$.

Examples:

-   In the category of sets and functions, a function
    $f: A \longrightarrow B$ is an isomorphism if and only if it is
    bijective.

-   In the category of groups and group homomorphisms (or rings and ring
    homomorphisms), a homomorphism $\phi: G \longrightarrow H$ is an
    isomorphism if it has an inverse map
    $\phi^{-1}: H \longrightarrow G$ which is also a homomorphism.

-   In the category of vector spaces and linear transformations, a
    linear transformation is an isomorphism if and only if it is an
    invertible linear transformation.

-   In the category of topological spaces and continuous maps, a
    continuous map is an isomorphism if and only if it is a
    homeomorphism.
